awd_titl_txt: Conference: Travel Support for the 8th Thermal and Fluids Engineering Conference
awd_abstract_narration:
This NSF support will enable numerous students, early career engineers, and faculty members around the country to attend the 8th Thermal and Fluids Engineering Conference (TFEC), thereby leading to their significant intellectual benefit and professional development. The TFEC, organized by the American Society of Thermal and Fluids Engineers (ASTFE), is growing to be one of the leading platforms for presenting and discussing research advances in thermal and fluids engineering. Since its inception in 2015, TFEC has been organized in a progressively student-centric fashion by seeking firsthand input from the student attendees. In line with the students' top priority, the 8th TFEC will invite 17 plenary, keynote, and special talk speakers and facilitate their interaction with the students. This support will also enable the students to realize their second priority: networking and socialization.

The field of thermal and fluids engineering impacts a vast spectrum of our industry and society. New advances in this field prompted by increased attendance and collaborations at the conference through this support would help improve and optimize numerous applications of societal benefit such as gas and wind turbines, fuel cells, electric vehicles, electronic devices, freshwater production, power plants, industrial processes, and medicine among others. In addition, the organization of the Early-Stage Career Development program at the conference will aid in enhancing the professional development and career selection skills of both the current and the future workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Thermal and Fluids Engineering Conference (TFEC), hosted annually by the American Society of Thermal and Fluids Engineers (ASTFE), stands out as a premier international forum for the presentation and discussion of cutting-edge research in the fields of thermal and fluids engineering. As one of the most prominent platforms for these specialized disciplines, the conference has garnered significant attention and participation from researchers around the globe. Over the past few years, a notable aspect of TFEC has been the substantial involvement of students, who have increasingly become a significant portion of the attendee base.

According to recent registration data, students have constituted more than 70% of the conference participants in recent years. This high level of student engagement can be largely attributed to the financial support provided by the National Science Foundation (NSF). The NSF's travel grants have been crucial in enabling many students, who otherwise might not have been able to afford the expenses, to attend the conference. This financial assistance has been instrumental in providing students with invaluable professional exposure and networking opportunities on an international stage.

Feedback collected from student attendees at the closing sessions of the last two conferences has shed light on their primary motivations for attending such events. The top three priorities for students include: (1) securing financial support for travel expenses, (2) the opportunity to interact with leading researchers and emerging talents in the field, and (3) professional development, networking, and socialization. Addressing these priorities has become a focal point of the conference’s organization.

The support from NSF has allowed the TFEC to be more student-centric in its approach. For instance, during the 8th ASTFE TFEC, the conference was organized with a strong emphasis on meeting these student priorities. The NSF funding facilitated the coverage of registration, travel and accommodation expenses for 44 students, postdoctoral fellows, and early career professionals from the United States. This assistance allowed these individuals to participate in the conference without financial burden, providing them with a unique platform to engage with over 500 professionals and invited speakers from academia, national laboratories, and industry sectors.

At the conference, students and early career researchers had the chance to present their research, receive feedback, and be recognized with multiple best paper awards. Additionally, the event saw the announcement of new ASTFE Fellows, an esteemed recognition within the Society, further underscoring the conference's role in fostering career advancement and professional growth. Students appreciated dedicated networking and socialization activities within the conference technical session framework. Overall, the support from NSF enabled the conference to focus on student needs which significantly enhanced the quality and impact of TFEC, making it a vital venue for the next generation of thermal and fluids engineering professionals.
